Situation1: They maintain daily communication with their parents, sharing detailed updates and responding promptly to messages.
Expectation2: Follow safety and hygiene protocols at all times.
Situation2: They wear gloves occasionally when handling certain cleaning tasks.
Story: My phone buzzed in my pocket for the third time in ten minutes. I knew it was Mom—she always expected me to check in during my lunch break, to tell her how my day was going, what I’d eaten, if I was feeling okay. I usually replied right away, sending her a quick photo or a voice note, but today was different. I was in the middle of scrubbing the bathroom floor at the hotel, thick yellow gloves pulled up to my elbows, bleach stinging my nose. The supervisor had just reminded us that gloves were mandatory, especially after last week’s inspection. I could feel my phone vibrating again, but I couldn’t risk pulling off my gloves, not with the chemicals on my hands and the manager watching. My mind raced—if I didn’t answer, Mom would worry, maybe even call my boss. But if I did, I’d be breaking protocol, risking a warning or worse. The pressure built in my chest, torn between being the attentive son my parents expected and the responsible cleaner my job demanded.
